coredata.dc:title: Electrolyte solutions between uncharged walls
coredata.dc:creator: Kjellander, Roland
Marčelja, Stjepan
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The anisotropic hypernetted chain approximation is applied to calculate the ion concentration profiles, the pair distribution functions and the surface-surface interaction between two uncharged slabs immersed in a primitive model electrolyte solution. The dielectric constant of the slabs is much smaller than that of the solvent. The full complexity of this problem is considered without further approximations. At short surface separations the ions are largely expelled from the space between the slabs due to repulsive image charge interactions. The pressure results clearly demonstrate the interdependence of the image charge interactions and the dispersion interactions between the slabs.

The slabs have a dielectric constant different from that of the solvent. They remain uncharged, and interact with the ions as hard walls and via the po- larization charges induced at their surface (image in- teractions). The electrolyte solution is described within the primitive model, i.e. the solvent is mo- delled as a dielectric continuum and the ions as charged hard spheres. The radii of the anions and the cations are identical, so we have complete charge symmetry. In the traditional theory of interactions between colloid particles, the DLVO theory [1], the inter- particle force is the sum of two contributions: the dispersion force between the dielectric media as cal- culated by the Hamaker or the Lifshitz theory and the contribution from the ions as given by the Poisson Boltzmann (PB) thoery. In the present case of uncharged surfaces, the latter contribution is zero. Since the dispersion force is calculated for the sys- tem in the absence of ions, it is assumed that the dis- persion interaction between the particles is unaffected by the presence of the ions. In practice, this is true for the non-zero-frequency (infrared to ultraviolet) contributions to the dispersion interaction, because the ion response is too slow. However, with regard to the zero-frequency term of the Lifshitz theory [2], this assumption is incorrect. Thus, the DLVO theory 1. Introduction The study of interactions between electro-neutral particles in electrolyte solutions is interesting for several reasons. At increased salt concentrations, the behaviour of dispersions of uncharged colloidal par- ticles, solutions of neutral macromolecules and ag- gregates of non-ionic surfactants is fairly complex. There are examples where the solute precipitates ( salting out ) and others where the solubility in- creases ( salting in ). The added salt will shield the dispersion interaction between the particles. The an- ions or the cations can preferentially adsorb to the initially uncharged particles, making each particle gain a charge and set up a diffuse double layer. Since the (static) polarizability of the particles is likely to be different from that of the solvent, there will be image charge interactions affecting the ion distri- bution near each particle. There are also important contributions to the interactions from solvation pro- cesses, solvation (or hydration ) forces. In order to gain insight into the fundamental mechanisms affecting the interactions between un- charged particles, it is important to study well-de- fined model systems, where one can separately focus attention on one of the many different effects, each of which represents a complex phenomenon. It includes the interactions due to correlations in the polarization fluctuations of the dielectric media (dispersion forces), but it neglects the interactions due to cor- relations in charge density fluctuations of the ionic medium and their dependence on the polarization response of the particles (image charge interactions of the ions). The inconsistency of DLVO theory can be re- moved by generalizing the Lifshitz theory to include fluctuations in charge density of the electrolyte phase, treating all electrostatic fluctuation interactions on the same level. This has been carried out by Ninham and Parsegian [3] on the basis of the linearized Poisson Boltzmann equation. The result is that the zero-frequency dispersion force between the dielec- tric media is screened and decays at increasing sur- face separation essentially in an exponential manner. However, in this approach the ion density through- out the space between the slabs is assumed to be equal to the bulk density, and the charge fluctuations are not accurately described since the ion ion correla- tions are treated at the level of the Debye Huckel theory. The severity of these assumptions has never been tested. Using both formally exact and approximate (but accurate) methods, Attard, Kjellander, Mitchell and Jonsson [4,5] studied the electrostatic fluctuation interactions including the contributions from the ion ion correlations in a related, but simpler sys- tem: two identical uncharged slabs on which all ions of the system were adsorbed but free to move along the surface. The slabs were separated by a phase con- sisting of pure solvent. The results highlight the in- terdependence of the various fluctuation contribu- tions to the pressure. The exact analysis [51 showed that unless the dispersion interactions and the image charge interactions were treated consistently, ficti- tious pressure contributions can be introduced that may even change the qualitative results. In this case the ions also screen the dispersion interaction. This screening is manifested [4,5] as a repulsive pressure contribution from the image charge interactions that identically cancels the zero-frequency dispersion term calculated in the absence of the ions. In the present system with an electrolyte solution between the surfaces, the ion density changes with surface separation, and it is important to treat the density distribution and the ion ion correlations as weil as the image and the dispersion interactions self- consistently. The ion density is strongly affected by the image charge interactions. If the dielectric con- stant of the walls is less than that of the solvent, the image interactions are repulsive and at short surface separations the ions are largely expelled from the space between the walls. The external pressure (in the bulk that surrounds the system), which at large separations is balanced by the internal pressure be- tween the walls, will therefore constitute a large part of the net pressure at short separations (at least if the bulk electrolyte concentration is reasonably high). In this paper we shall use the powerful anisotropic hypernetted chain (HNC) approximation to treat this problem. This approximation gives accurate re- sults for systems with long-range interactions. Most importantly, within the primitive model it allows for a complete treatment of all the complications men- tioned above without any further approximations [6 8] and generally with only minor additional ef- fort compared to calculations on the corresponding closed system without image interactions. We may note that compared to simulation tech- niques, these features make the anisotropic HNC method very attractive. Since simulations take place in real space, there is no easy way to include multiple images in the interaction potentials. The best option is probably to tabulate the potential function, since it constitutes a slowly converging series (while it is a closed, analytic expression in Fourier space, which is utilized in the HNC method). To obtain the proper force curve as a function of surface separation, one must do the calculations under the condition of con- stant chemical potential (open system). A straight- forward simulation would thus require a grand canonical ensemble study with multiple images in- cluded in ail interactions, i.e. very laborious calcu- lations. There has been no such study to date. 2. Method The anisotropic HNC theory used in the calcula- tions is described in ref. [7]. The Omstein Zernike equation and the HNC closure for the anisotropic pair correlation functions are combined with an equation for the density profiles that utilizes the ex- 486 Volume 142, number 6 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 25 December 1987 plicit HNC expression for the chemical potential. Given the chemical potential for the bulk solution with which the system is in equilibrium, a self-con- sistent solution can be obtained by a double iterative procedure [7,8]. The interaction potentials arising from the multiple images are explicitly included us- ing the analytic, closed formula in Fourier space. The long-range tail of the direct correlation function due to the electrostatic ion ion and ion image charge potentials is subtracted and treated analytically. Li- kewise, the discontinuity of the correlation function at the hard-core diameter and the accompanying long-range tail in Fourier space are eliminated and treated analytically. For further details see refs. [7,9]. As we have seen, this leads to quantitatively inaccurate pressures at all separations. In real applications of these results, the higher-fre quency contributions to the dispersion interaction have to be added. In contrast to the zero-frequency term, these are not screened by the electrolyte and remain long-range [21. Accordingly, they will dom inate in the pressure at large distances.
